DOC.HEAD: Grain Markets Slip In Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices slipped in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, with much of the selling stemming from warming temperatures in the Great Plains and Midwest. Moderating temperatures after a two-week spell of severely cold weather eased transportation problems as well as demand for livestock feed. Early selling in the soybean market also was linked to reports of light rain in southern Brazil over the weekend and forecasts for more moisture in that area, one of the world's major soybean-producing pockets. It is early summer in Brazil. Dry weather during the planting season had stirred drought fears, but those concerns have faded as growing conditions improved in recent weeks. In early trading, wheat futures were 1 cent lower to 1 cent higher with the contract for delivery in March at $4.10} a bushel; corn futures were \ cent to } cent lower with March at $2.38\ a bushel; oat futures were 1 cent to 1\ cents lower with March at $1.53 a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 3\ cents lower with January at $5.69 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, which also reflected the warmer temperatures in the nation's midsecton. Live cattle futures were .10 cent lower to .10 cent higher with February at 76.70 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .02 cent to .10 cent lower with January at 84.72 cents a pound; live hogs were .03 cent to .28 cent lower with February at 48.62 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .35 cent to .55 cent lower with February at 49.27 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled mixed on Friday. The markets were closed Monday.
